div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: THE COOLING OF THE ENTENTE.
div.p: The writer of the chronique on foreign affairs in the "Fortnightly Review is not in a happy frame of mind this month, though he does not express his discontent with the unrestraint of his brother chronicler of the "National," whose prodigal use of denunciatory adjectives it would be hopeless to attempt to rival. He is a whole-hearted supporter of the entente cordiale with France, and he believes that the sentiment in its favour is beginning to cool. He is profoundly suspicious of the policy of Germany, and he laments the growth of more cordial relations between the two peoples.
In France and elsewhere human nature ought not to be human nature, but it is:-

"There is no definite change of opinion, but there it a change of feeling. The temperature of the entente cordiale is falling, not rifting. France distrusts the flexibility of our proceed ings and the apparent fluidity of our sentiments. The Gallic mind it as prone to suspicion as the German to envy—as Bismarck said —or the British to pharisaism. We have all our faults. It is a duty to reckon with them, and not build our political ideas upon the theory of a human perfection which can never exist in international relations. There has always been a stronger counter-current to the entente cor diale than we have thought it decent to admit. The Nationaliste have never quite forgiven us for our attitude in the Dreyfus case. The Clericals do not understand the predilections even of British Conservatives, who are firm supporters of religions education and the Established Church in this country, for sépara tion and secularism across the Channel There is in addition, a small but definite school of trained politicians who believe that an ultimate alliance with Germany will be found inevitable, and that a continuance of the present policy — in the absence of any possibility of sufficient military support from this country—would mean probable destruction. It is our present business to note these views, not to analyse them The classes indicated form altogether a minority, but they are a strong minority, and the current is now running in their favour."

The meeting at Wilbelmsnobe has not made a good impression upon a certain section of French opinion. "Following on a series of effusive Anglo German fraternisations the sense of sceptical weariness felt in Paris was natural enough, though unfortunate." But, he admits with grudging reluctance, the meeting was hailed by the rest of the world with astonishing optimism, and he even concedes that "it was in many ways an admirable thing" :—

"It removed once for all the mischievous legend of a personal antagonism between the Kaiser and the King Whatever our views upon foreign issues may be, nothing could be in worse taste or of more evil effect than to encourage the view that the great diplomatic and naval issues in which Great Britain and Germany are concerned can be affected in any way by the private relations of their monarchs. The German Press greeted the occasion with a unanimity of compliment of this country unequalled for the better part of a generation." He regards the problem of how to improve our relations with Germany while not cooling our cordiality with Franceas well nigh insoluble, and believes that we shall end in a collapse between two stools.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and O.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half past four this afternoon.

div.head: Irrigation Employe Dismissed.
div.p: Hussein Effendi Nadim, engineer of the Irrigation department of the Ministry of Public Works has been dismissed and his rights to pension forfeited.

div.head: The Mex Baths
div.p: The baths, cafe, and restaurant at Mex will remain open all the year round. The tramcar time table will be the same as during the summer, the last tram leaving Mex at 1 a.m.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Five cases of plague are recorded for Egypt during the week ending October 14th. This brings the total up to 1107 for this year, while during the same period in 1906 only 492 cases were recorded.

div.head: The Victoria College.
div.p: Yesterday was the opening day of the winter term at Victoria College, Alexandria, and the students assembled in full force. Several applications for admission to the school have had to be rejected owing to lack of accommodation.

div.head: Protection of Infants.
div.p: The proposal of a group of Alexandrian Moslems for the establishment of institutions for the shelter and protection of abandonded infants and young children will come before the Municipal Commission this week. It is said that a sum of L.E. 1,000 will be granted to the society formed to carry out the project.

div.head: The Russian Affair.
div.p: Mr. Georges Ralli, who has been sentenced by the Native Court of Alexandria to one month's imprisonment for having taken part in the Russian manifestations of some months back, has appealed. He is awaiting his papers in order to prove Hellenic nationality.

div.head: Alexandria Ramleh Line.
div.p: Two new bogey cars have just arrived for the Alexandria and Ramleh Electric Railways. They are bigger than the prescrit cars and the seats are transversal. If they are found to be successful orders will he sent for a farther supply. The equipments are by Dick Ken & Co., the bodies by the Brush Co., and the bogies by the Brill Co, U S.A. It may lie mentioned that these cars can be opened in the summer and closed in winter The double deck car of this type will seat 116 passengers when open and the single deck rar 60 passengers. These cars are first and second class. In the former there are neat racks for the carriage of small parcels over each seat The public are sure to be satisfied with these cars, which represent the most up to date ideas both in comfort and mechanical ingenuity.

div.head: PUBLIC SECURITY.
To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette"
div.p: Dear Sir,- I am a cotton merchant and a landowner at Dessouk, and I beg to bring before the notice of the public through the medium of your generous columns, an unpar-el deled example of the manner in which the administration of justice is baulked at every turn in this country. Rather more than a week ago I was returning from my esbeh to my house at Dessouk on donkey back when I was, on approaching the bridge, violently assaulted by a Saidi named Ramadan employed by the State Railways Administration tor the opening and closing of the bridge. Not having any means of protection with me, save my fists, I was cruelly beaten about the head and upper part of the body with a nabout by the said Hindi, and was rendered unconscious. Assistance, happily, was close at hand and some of my employés rescued me and carried me to the house The police were called in, an enquiry was made, and it was finally derided to arrest Ramadan. At this point, however, the Sheikh of the Esbeh El Koshla interfered and refused to allow the arrest of Ramadan, saying that he was a Government employe. The police, with somewhat remarkable willingness, acquiesce ed. Since then, knowing the annoyances tn which one his subjected by following up such cases, I have not taken further measures tn have Ramadan punished, but I wish to record this case as a warning to those who are inclined to believe that one can meet with fair treatment at the hands of the police. I am prepared to guarantee the accuracy of all the statements which I have made, and to offer the same on the Government authorities should they awaken to the fact that such cases require attention.
Yours truly NIKOLA CHARIDIS.
Alexandria, October 16.

[There is considerable dissatisfaction among Europeans dwelling in the villages owing to the want of organisation in the provincial police force. Of late there has been a recrudesence of anti-European feeling in the villages owing to the fanaticism of the vernacular Moslem Press and there appears to be considerable alarm owing to this want of security. Ed. E. G.]

div.head: BLUNT'S SECRET HISTORY.
HIS REPLY TO MALET
div.p: Mr. Wilfred Scawen Blunt, replying to Sir E. Malet in the "Times" states that he had no intention to imply that Sir E. Malet was withdrawn from his post. Mr. Blunt implored Sir Edward Hamilton that Sir Edward Malet should be got away as his life was threatened. Sir Edward Malet's belief that the fever was the effect of poisoning justified his warning.

div.head: OPHTHALMIC HOSPITALS IN EGYPT.
div.p: Ophthalmic disease has been for many years one of the greatest scourges under which Egypt has to labour, and it is therefore comforting to read Dr. MacCallan's pamphlet regarding the measures which have, of recent years, been organized to overcome it.

The formation of ophthalmic hospitals in Egypt was due in the first place to the generosity of Sir Ernest Cassel, who gave a sum of £41,000 to be devoted to the relief of ophthalmic sufferers amongst the poorer inhabitants of Egypt.

As a result of this donation, the Direct General of the Department of Public Health proposed the formation of a travelling hospital, and Dr. MacCallan was appointed Ophthalmic Surgeon and Inspector to the new Department.
He arrived in Egypt to take up his new duties in July 1903, and proceeded to make a tour of inspection in the Delta, taking with him an Egyptian assistant from the Government hospital in Cairo.

As a result of this tour, during which many cases were attended to, Dr. MacCallan was convinced that the scheme of travelling hospitals was a thoroughly practicable one, though it was at the same time evident that in order to succesfully deal with the large number of patients who applied for treatment, it would be necessary to work on a very large scale.

In order to deal as fairly as possible with the different provinces, it was decided to establish the hospital in one district for a period of about six months, transferring it at the expiration of that time to another district, and so on.

Even so, the time alloted is far from being adequate to the need of the various districts, but until the establishment of permanent hospitals, it is the only method by which the worst cases are enabled to come forward for treatment, for, as Dr. MacCallan remarks, the majorty of patients have every appearance of poverty.

Sir Ernest Cassel coming forward a second time with a donation for the same cause, rendered the formation of a second hospital possible, and for the past three years, Upper and Lower Egypt have each had a travelling hospital of its own working under the direction of Dr. MacCallan: Menouf, Galioub, Zagazig, Damietta, Damanhour, Beni-Sued, Fayoum and Assiout having been visited up to the present time

During the time that the hospital was at the latter town, the inhabitants, seeing the great benefits which resulted from the treatment, subscribed a sum of £50,000 towards the expense of building an ophthalmic hospital for their city.

Dr. MacCallan speaks in the highest terms of his Egyptian assitant whose interest and energy in their work he describes as gratifying. During the year 1906, 40,103 patients were examined at the hospitals of which 7,327 were treated, which is sufficient proof of the excellent work achieved.

Dr. MacCallan speaks hopefully of the boys now being educated at the Government schools being trained to the comprehension of ophthalmic hygiene, though he admits that it is quite beyond the powers of the uneducated Egyptian.

An ophthalmic hospital is to be opened at Tantah this year, and an arrangement has been made between the Ministries of Public Health and of Public Instruction, whereby a daily inspection of the scholars at the Government school there mau be made in order to deal directly with ophthalmic disease.

The pamphlet from which we have quoted only a portion of the detail it contains, is a concise record for the work accomplished during the past four years: it also contains statistics of the persons who came forward for treatment in the year 1906, and will prove to be the most interesting work to all who are interested in the subject of ophthalmia and its effects upon the people of Egypt.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN BALE
div.p: Among the recommendations of the committee on the growing and handling of cotton submitted to the Convention of Cotton Growers and Spinners are the following:-
That the Egyptian form of bale, which has one more binder, he adopted as possible, and the burlap he used instead of jute.

That all cotton, after picking, be housed for forty days before ginning, in order to meet the European spinners' complaint of dampness, which, it is alleged, is not acquired in the holds of the ships.

That the planters individually or by communities, do their own ginning and compressing, so as to free themselves from the exacting, so as to free themselves from the exactions of the so-called Compress Trust, and to permit direct handling from the planters to the spinners.

div.head: MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
THE LAMBERT AFFAIR
div.p: The letter of M. Lambert to the "Temps" was published in "Al Lewa" some days before the arrival of the mail containing the Parisian newspaper of that date, October 8th. The combination between the late Franco-Egyptian official and the Nationalist leader is instructive and lends countenance to the report that Kamel has receieved material assistance from French sources in return for which he suddenly ceased attacking France for avenging the massacre of Europeans at Casablanca.

The letter of M. Lambert which we reproduced from "Al Lewa" in our issue of Friday last, has appeared in the "Temps" with some emendations of the text as originally handed to Kamel by Lambert. Thus it is that, in three cases some alterations have been introduced, viz:
(a) In the sentence:-

"I renounced this position not without a real pang, because...... I could maintain myself...... only on the condition of being the blind instrument of a policy as incorrect, as it was compromising......" The word incorrectly has been changed for the word guilty.
(b)Instead of the sentence:-
"A joke of a particularly doubtful character......hastened my decision.
M. Lambert wrote:-

"A last incident hastened my decision. After having authorised me, verbally it is true, but in a formal way and at two different dates, to leave Cairo for my yearly holidays on June 19; after having informed himself by questioning me personally upon the matter that I had retained and paid for my berth on the boat; after having let me send off my baggage and say goodbye to my friends. Mr. Dunlop let me know, barely twelve hours prior to the hour in which I ought to have gone on board, that he withdrew the authorisation previously given and wished me to remain in Cairo until I should receive further orders. The publicity given to this measure, both in the Ministry and in my school, gave it the aspect of a punishment or pensum, and did not permit me to accept it without placing me in a deconsiderate position vis-a-cis my collaborators and my scholars.
(c) To the last sentence:-

"It is very improbably that we shall ever be able to find a more propitous opportunity for reconstituting the monopoly of Law education which was torn from our hands in 1899", add-"when the English section of the Khedivial School of Law was created."

Those who take an interest in the trend of political events in Egypt almost unanimously consider that an answer should be given to the charges made by M. Lambert against Mr. Dunlop, but since the Adviser to the Ministry of Public Instruction has apparently decided to follow, even in this extreme case, his well-known policy of silence, it is difficult to see how the interest of the public can be satisfied. The Government might request Saad Pasha Zagloul to refute the accusations of the ex-Director of the Khedivial Law School, but this could hardly be done without the consent of the Adviser, which is hardly likely to be given. We may take it for granted, however, that since officialdom maintains silence on such an important matter and since Mr. Dunlop still occupies one of the highest posts in the country, the Government are fully satisfied with his conduct of educational reform.

div.head: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: Sir,—It must be a matter of exceeding astonishment to globe-trotters, and visitors to Egypt, that whereas the Ministry of Public Works, have the handling annually of enormous sums, yet so far, since the time of the British occupation, nothing whatever has been devoted to the construction of roads, not as one understands from an engineering point of view. That they are wanted and desired is amply manifest, from the use made of the agricultural tracks that stretch out a few miles from some of the towns of the interior, and a road as a start off from Cairo to Helouan would no doubt be one of immense popularity. The erroneous impression seems to prevail that the Egyptian State Railways, and Delta Light Railways are all sufficing, but perhaps carriersof stone, camel drivers, contractors, etc., to say nothing of automobiliste, may have something further to say on the matter
I am, etc. Traveller.
October 15.

div.head: To The Editor of The "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: Sir.— Your article of 12th inst. under the above beading, is one that all true believers in progress must heartily appreciate, for it points out a great need that has long been felt Not only would road communication from the capital to Helouan be a matter of incalculable advantage to the latter; but would be a boon to Egypts' chief city, and add considerably to Egypts' attractions in general. On no other Bank of Cairo could a road be constructed that would afford greater satisfaction ; be one fraction so cheap to model; or pass through a pleasanter or more picturesque stretch of country.
I am, Sir, Yours truly "Progress."
Helouan, October 15.

div.head: SEPTEMBER CUSTOMS RETURNS.
div.p: During last month the value of goods imported into Egypt was L.E. 2,031,047, being L.E. 66,721 less than September 1906, while for the ninth months' period with an import value of L.E. 18,447,115 an increase of L.E. 1,988,479 is shown. Last month the exports totalled L.E. 1,045,778, against L.E. 908,336 during September 1906, and since the 1st of January L.E. 16,402,116 against L.E. 13,642,911.

div.head: EXCHANGE OF SPECIE.
div.p: The total of specie imported last month was L.E. 588,481 as compared with L.E. 1,116,900 in September 1906. During the first nine months of the year the import of specie was L.E. 2,917,624as compared with L.E. 1,768,079 in the corresponding period of the last year. Of the L.E. 2,917,624imported between January 1and September 30, L.E. 1,143,603 came from Turkey and L.E. 1,409,193from England:

The specie exported during last month was L.E. 56,053as compared with L.E. 24,171in September 1906; and for the ninth months' period the figures are L.E. 4,645,481and L.E. 1,995,126, respectively for 1907 and 1906. The last import of specie therefore exceeds that of last year up to September 30by L.E. 1,149,545; while the excess of exported specie for the same period is L.E. 2,650,355. Of the exported specie in ninth months L.E. 2,107,003went to England L.E. 1,700,843to India, L.E. 465,700to Turkey, and L.E. 339,727to France.

div.head: CIGARETTE TRADE
div.p: The total export of cigarettes during September was 42,834 kilos, as compared with 37,742, and from the 1st of Januaryto 30th Septemberthe figures recorded for 1907 and 1906 respectively are 363,560 kilos, and 466,799 kilos. Of the 363,560 kilos, exported during the past nine months 113,015 went to Germany; 63,779 to England; 52,236 to British possessions in the Far East; 31,955 to Austro-Hungary; 24,356 to Norway and Sweden; 18,875 to China and the Far East; 18,277 to France; 11,932 to America; and 8,981 to Belgium. Comparing the first nine months of 1907 with those of 1906 exports to Germany show a decrease of 116,926; England an increase of 159; British possessions in the Far East a decrease of 2,252; Austro-Hungary a decrease of 1,777; Norway and Sweden an increase of 9,282; China and the Far East an increase of 2,112; France an increase of 3,800; America an increase of 6,103; and Belgium an increase of 416. While importing 12,289 kilos between January 1and September 30, 1907, this year Switzerland has only imported 105 kilos.

div.head: "WISDOM OF THE EAST."
div.p: The editors of the "Wisdom of the East" series who state that they have spared no pains to secure the best specialists for the treatment of the various subject, have just issued "Arabian Wisdom" by John Wortabet, M.D., and published by John Murray, London, prince 1/s. This volume, like the others, is charming in form, low in price and excellent in matter. The contents include the chapter and other renderings of the Koran, for which the author declares himself wholly responsible. The volume is full of wise sayings in many subjects such as character, friends, neighbors, marriage, children, youth and old age and may be read with pleasure by both old and young.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Ottoman High Commissioner will return to Cairo from Alexandria on the 11th prox.

Mustapha Pasha Fahmy arrived at Cairo yesterday evening at a quarter past seven. The Prime Minister was met at the station by a large number of officials and notables of Cairo. On alighting from the train he was greeted by his fellow-Ministers and Sir Elden Gorst, among others, and after cordially shaking hands with all assembled to meet him he drove off to his residence.
Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Cairo, accompanied the Prime Minister to the Capital yesterday.
Mr. Paul de Reffye, French Consul at Cairo, has returned to the capital from his holiday in Europe.
The Khedive has conferred the first class order of the Medjidieh on Sir Vincent Corbett in recognition of his services during his tenure of the Financial Advisership.
The Sultan has conferred the Grade of Oula on Emir Kabalan Abilamma, president of the Administrative Council of Mount Lebanon.

Mr. H. H. Lamb, Chief Dragoman of the British Embassy at Constantinople, succeeds Mr. Graves as Consul-General at Selonika. Mr. G. H. Fitzmaurice, Second Dragonman, taking Mr. Lamb's place. Both are highly esteemed members of the Levant Consular service.

Ismail Bey Zouhdi, commandment of the Gharbieh police, who by his term of service is entitled to a pension of two-thirds of his salary, is about to tender his resignation on account of his failing health.
The death occurred yesterday at Assouan of the Rev. Chauncey Murch, D.D., a well-known American Missionary in Egypt, after an illness of very brief duration.

The death occured yesterday at the age of 75 years of Signora Matilde Vincon-Testa, (nee Martini) widow of the late Signor Vincon-Testa, of Cairo. The funeral took place at one o'clock this afternoonfrom the deceased house at No. 11 Rue Fagallah, Cairo.

Mr. Charles Rudy, late Editor of the "Egyptian Standard," has been relieved of all responsibility in connection with that news paper. Mustapha Pasha Kamels brother-in-has been appointed in the plane of Mr. Rudy. The Pasha seems to be somewhat capricious in regard to the Editors of his European papers. Neither the "Egyptian Standard" nor the "Etendard Egyptien" have existed for a year as yet, but in both cases the Editors have been changed. Mr. Rudy has had a very difficult journalistic task and, however much we may disagree with the principles of the "Standard," we must confess that the late Editor has succeeded far better than was generally anticipated.

Mr. McMillan, the well known -American millionaire who is a popular figure in Cairo society and a noted big game hunter, haspurchased from Mrs. David Garrick Longworth, wife of the former proprietor of our popular weekly season society Cairo contemporary the "Sphinx," a model of the famous Gizeh Sphinx, which took seven years to complete. The model is to be presented to the Field Colombian Museum in Cairo.

div.head: THOROUGHBREDS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: Eleven fine English thoroughbreds arrived at Alexandria from London by the 8.8. "Egyptian" (Captain Cherry) on Monday last They were in charge of Mr. T P Goodchild, of the Horse Breeding Commission of Egypt. These horses have been brought onto by the Egyptian Government in order to improve the country bred stock.

It is worth remarking that one of the English thoroughbreds which arrived by the S.S. "Egyptian" has Diamond Jubilee, the winner of the Derby, for his sire. This horse has won a race of the value of £2,500 amongst others and all the others are winners of races at home.

The same steamer brought out three English carthorses for the Cairo Dire Brigade, and two rams for the Breeding Commission, one of the Romney Marsh and the other of the Suffolk breed. A Welsh cob for Mr. Branch, of the Breeding Commission, also arrived by the Steamer. The nineteen horses which arrived on Monday at Alexandria by the Austro-Hungary Lloyd steamer from Trieste were shipped by Mr. Antoine Amato, the well-known Cairo horsedealer. They left yesterday for Cairo where they will be put up for auction.
Some fine horses also arrived on Monday by the North German Lloyd S.S. "Schleswig" for Mr. Amato.

div.head: POLO MATCHES
div.p: Two polo matches were played at Ghezireh yesterday, the first being Mr. Schreiber's team versus Major Haig's team, which was rather disappointing, the game being decidedly slow.
Mr. Schreiber's team won by 3 goals to 1.
Mr. Schreiber's Team. Mr. Tollemache I. Major Gillson II. Capt. Bailey III. Mr. Schreiber (back).
Major Haig's Team. Capt. Hen. C. Monek I. ,, Robert's II. Mr. Marsham III. Major Haig (back).
SECOND MATCH.

The Inniskilling Dragoons versus the King's Own Scottish Borderers was much more lively, the Dragoons winning by 4 goals to 2. The K.O.S.B. team, who have improved so wonderfully the last six months, had much the better of the first chukker and were unlucky not to score on several occasions. The second chukker the Dragoons were the attacking party and score 2 goals, Capt. Holland being especially conspicuous. Third chukker was a repetition of the second, two more goals being registered by the Dragoons, the K.O.S.B. seeming to tire. The last chukker the K.O.S.B. came again, and score 2 goals and very nearly added a third. Captain Stoney and Kennedy played extremely well.
K.O.S.B. Mr. Furber I. ,, Cobden II. Capt. Kennedy III. ,, Stoney IV.
Inniskilling Dragoons. Mr. Bowen I. Capt. Nixon II. ,, Holland III. Mr Bowen (back).

div.head: NEW POST OFFICE.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday.

The foundations of the new Government Post Office on the Avenue Helens at Port Tewfik, have already begun, and it is expected the building will shortly commence. The premises when complete will be similar to the Port Said Post Office, and will be used mostly for the foreign and transit mails to and from the East.

div.head: H.M.S. "Amphitrite."
div.p: The Special service first class cruiser "Amphitrite" is expected to arrive at Suez to-morrow morning with a relief crew for the recommissioning of the cruiser "Kent" at Colombo. The "Amphitrite" will coals at Suez, and then sail for Colombo direct.

div.head: WITHDRAWAL OF REBELS.
div.p: Aden, October 7.

Recent advices from Yemen state that the situation in Yemen is improving and the Imam is withdrawing his Chiefs. There is, however, still some trouble in the Turkish district, Humdan, which lies a few hours' march from Sans. The reason assigned for the withdrawal of the rebels is wide of the truth. There are more cogent and far more probable reasons than the return of the Yemen deputation from Constantinople. The approach of Ramadan, the sacred month, to begin with, in which hostilities are considered by the Imam as a sacrilege unless in a defensive position, and the excesses committed recently by some of the Imam's Chiefs in one or two places, and almost unprecedented rains are the real reasons of the rebels withdrawal. The Turkish troops who mutined at Amran and left for Hodeida have left that port.

div.head: KAMEL AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The following paragraph appears in Mustaphsa Kamel's English organ under the heading of "A Great Speech." The ridiculous egoistical strain of the paragraph appears also in the wording of the French version:-
Next Tuesday, on October 22, our director will pronounce in Alexandria in the Zinzinia Theatre, a great political speech.
He will speak about the greatness of the National Party, the goal he has in view, the necessity for all Egyptians to be grouped around him, as the only man who represented the Egyptian nation.
Our Director will answer all objections, all criticisms directed against the movement.

Our Director will insist upon the recognised necessity for all Egyptians to live in good relations with the foreign colonies in Egypt. If anything has arisen to disturb these peaceful relations, it is certainly not the ever kindly and hospitable dispositions of the Egyptian people towards strangers. These dispositions are always the same, in spite of the most violent and unjust attacks of certain European papers disavowed by the representatives of the foreign colonies. The utility of European aid as regards the progress of Egypt has never been denied by any patriot, and Egyptian independence will always be bent upon developing good relations among all foreigners without exception.

div.head: THE Hotel Casino San Stefano
div.p: Will be open during Winter
REDUCED PRICES

The Crewe to Bristol express, with Glasgow, Liverpool, York, and Hull coaches, left the curve entering Shrewsbury last night. Sixteen persons have been killed and many injured. All the coaches except the last one were derailed.
(Later). 19 persons have been killed and 40 injured. The engine turned turtle and the carriages were heaped to the height of telegraph poles. (Reuter)

div.head:
WHEAT IN ENGLAND.
CONTINUED HEAVY RISE.

div.p: The price of wheat in England is now 33/3 a quarter. It has risen an average of 4/- since 1st Octoberand 7/- since 1st Septemberand is still rising. This pertends exceptionally dear bread during the coming winter and is attributed to the smallness of the English yield, the poorness of foreign crops, and the failure of the area of supply to extend commeneurately with the world's demands. (Reuter)

div.head:
MORE BALLOON TRIALS.
A RECORD BROKEN.

div.p: The balloon "Mammoth" left the Crystal Palace on Saturday in the direction of Russia. It broke the oversea long distance record and descended on Sunday evening at Aamaal (West Sweden) empty. The three aeronauts escaped three hours previously in a Swedish village by sliding down the guild rope. The car has been badly damaged. (Reuter)

div.head:
WRECK OF A TRAMCAR.
SIX WORKMAN KILLED.

div.p: A workmen's tramcar was wrecked at Halifax this morning. It rushed down a steep bill, the brake failing to act. Three men were killed and 31 seriously injured.
(Later). Three more deaths have occurred. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE FLOODS IN FRANCE.
DEMAND FOR A CREDIT

div.p: The Government is asking for a credit of 6,000,000 france for the inundated provinces. (Reuter)

div.head:
COLLAPSE OF A BRIDGE.
TRAIN PRECIPITATED INTO RAVINE.

div.p: Middleton Bridge (New York State) has collapsed. A train has been precipitated into a ravine, 20 persons have been killed or injured. (Reuter)

div.head:
AUSTRIAN EMPEROR'S HEALTH..
UNEASINESS IN VIENNA.

div.p: The city is agitated by the conflicting reports with regard to the Emperor's health, in spite of the semi official announcement yesterday evening that a distinct turn for the better had taken place. (Reuter)
The strength of the Emperor is satisfactory and his temperature normal. His Majesty listened to the reading of the report on the Austro-Hungarian compromise. (Havas)

div.head:
HOME RAILWAY CRISIS.
LLOYD GEORGE INTERVIEWED.

div.p: Mr. Lloyd George, interviewed with regard to the railway situation, said that it was exceedingly delicate. It would be madness for him to say anything at such a serious juncture. He declined to say whether the Board of Trade would intervene. (Reuter)
It is expected that the railwaymen's ballot will be completed by 28th October. Enquiries at the branches of the Association indicate that the majority are in favour of a strike.
(Reuter)

div.head:
PORTSMOUTH'S NEW DOCK.
APPROVAL OF PLANS.

div.p: The plans have been finally approved for the new dock at Portsmouth to accomodate the Dreadnoughts. It will be 900 feet long and 100 wide and will cost £1,000,000 (Reuter)

div.head:
EXPLOSION OF POWDER WORKS.
21 PERSONS KILLED.

div.p: Powder works have been blown up at Fontanet (Indiana). 21 persons have been killed. (Reuter)
The Channel and Home fleets, with the cruiser squadrons, were mustered yesterday to begin a fortnight's secret maneuvres in the North Sea. Lord Charles Beresford will direct operations. (Reuter)
It is confirmed that Ben Smassen is recommencing agitation around Udjda. (Havas)
M.M. Cambon and De Tschirsky have conferred as to the Casablanca indemnities. (Havas)
A meeting of workmen declared a general strike until Friday. (Havas)
The national democratic party has triumphed in the Duma elections at Lodz. (Havas)
A new case of plague has been notified. (Havas)
The "Superb," the latest Dreadnought, will be launched at Elswick on 7th April. (Reuter)
Cesarewitch Stakes Betting: 3 to 1 Baltin Grass; 6 to 2 Demure; 8 to 1 Royal Dream; 9 to 1 Madame De Soubise; 10 to 1 Wuffy: 100 to 7 Outbreak; 100 to 6 The White Knight. (Reuter)

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit within certain necessary limited-free discussion.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM
HATRED OF THE SYRIANS.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette,"

Sir,-I read in the "Gazette" of the 27th ult, under the "National Leaders" the view of Hafiz Awad, and I beg to explain to the readers of the "Egyptian Gazette" that the views of this man are not sound but franatical to the utmost degree.
The Egyptian nation is composed of:-
1st. The very Egyptian, the Copts.
2nd. The Arab or Turkish Mohamedans of whom is Hafiz Awad, Mustafa Kamel and their friends.
3rd. The Syrians who live in the country from many centuries ago and most of them are descendants of high families well known to historians.

The Syrians are of a very intelligent and honest racem the best writers in Egypt are Syrians, the best merchants are Syrians, you never hear that a Syrian has robbed a bank or took bashish from the inhabitants.
Hafiz Awad hates the Syrians because they are his literary superior and can lay no claim to be such a writer as lakander Shabeer, the Syrian who is the first Arabic writer in Egypt.
In short all the leading Arabic papers are edited by the brave Syrian writers.

Hafiz Awad and his friends want to use their papers to move the Egyptians to agitation and then to revolution; but they were and are checked by the gallant Syrian writers, who explained to the public the dangerous ideas and views of those who veil their fanatic acts by the word "Nationalism" and the Egyptian nation never authorized the false pretenders to represent them, and it is on the contrary the public dislike these agitators who are drawing the country to ruin.

I interviewed more than one member of the Legislative council who told me that Hafiz Awad and Mustafa Kamel are known to the Egyptians only as merchants who want to collect money from the inhabitants under the pretention that they were defending the Egyptians against the English.

The special correspondent of the "Times" writes from Beyrouth on the Syrian he said "They are sharp witted folk with an intelligence that is more European, that is more ratiocinative and controlled to a greater extent by conscious logical process, than the Egyptians whose minds never seem to have room for more than a few fixed quasi-instinctive ideas which he may attempt to defend, but at which he seldom seems to arrive, with the aid of reason."
Then in another paragraph the special correspondent of the "Times" said "In enterprise, courage, self-respect, and freedom from petty crime they are (the Syrians) far am[eropr to the Egyptians."
The Syrio-Egyptians are the cousins of those Syrians whom the special correspondent believes to be nearer to Europeans more than other oriental nations.
Hafiz Awad had better know his place and that he is unequal to any Syrio-Egyptian in every respect.

My late teacher Lawrence Oliphant who has been to many parts of the world and lived in Syria for about three years told me once that the Christians Syrians are of the sharpest witted people he ever met.
Yours truly,
Thunder.
Medinet el Fayoum, October 13.

Later I noticed swellings in my ankles, which spread up my legs so rapidly that I had to cease work and take to bed. div.head: NOVEL READING FROM THE PULPIT.
div.p: Having been told about the New York Minister who employed two coloured ministrels and a whistling lady to attract a congregation, we are not much surprised to learn from the "Telegraph's" correspondent that an American clergyman has taken to reading a novel from the pulpit.

The Rev. Guy Christopher Jamieson, of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Tottenville, Staten Island, despairing of finding a publisher for his novel, entitled "Captain Jack's Club," which is understood to convey a sound moral lesson or two in 80,000 words, struck upon the desperate device of reading the same to his congregation from his church pulpit.

According to the "Telegraph's" correspondent he read the first instalment on Sunday night week. It was evidently a labour of love, and lasted half an hour, and then he blandly announced, not "to be continued in our next," but, "that, dear Christian friends, will be enough for this evening." The pious author had brought his listeners to the exciting point; where the hero of the nove, Paul Gilmer-who, by the way, is an Episcopal clergyman-helps a young lady over a stile, and is being blushingly thanked.

Mr. Jamieson justifies himself for reading his manuscript in the pulpit on the ground of dwindling congregation, and he believes that a really good pulpit novel will achieve more success than the average sermon and few here disput him.

div.head: HAM BROWN'S CONFESSION.
div.p: There is the very remarkable passage in the late Haji A. Brown's recently published book. "Bonaparte in Egypt and Egyptians of To-day," on the difficulty of becoming a follower of the Prophet:-

"Abandoning all that he has been, he must seek to become that which he is not, and, sever ing his life from all that has made it his, forego his tastes, stifle hi* prejudices, ignore his predilections, suppress his emotions, thwart his inclinations, and laughing when he would weep, weep when he would laugh. And with this slaying of his own individuality he must in all things strive to identify himself with those alien to him. ever seeking to see, hear, think and acts they do. And he must do this not for a week, a month or a year, but for many years. Not in one city, town or country, hut in several ; not merely mixing as best he may with the wealthy and the poor, the illterate and the learned, but, learning to be at home in the abodes of the prosperous and I the haunts of the miserable, become equally so with the merchant in the bazaar and the wandering fakir in the desert. And through it all he must ever be other than his home life and training have made him, ceaselessly on the alert to detect the nature, feelings and impulses of others and to hide his own. And he must be and do all this day and night, in the loneliness of the desert as in the busy haunts of men. And in doing this he is treading a road over which there is no return. The further he goes the more perfect is his success, the more impossible it becomes for him to regain his starting point. Never again can he be that which he has been before. He may quit the East, return to the home of his childhood and mix again with his fellows as one of them, but he ran never recover the place he has left and lost, for he who goes down into the East, though his heart never cease to yearn for home and the things of home, is daily, slowly, imperceptibly, yet surely, being estranged, and be goes home to find that he no longer has a home, that neither in the blast nor in the West is there any rest for him Thenceforth and forever he is alone in the world and, with his own sympathies enlarged and entered, can hope for no sympathy, no fellowship amidst all the teeming millions of the earth."

div.head: JEWS IN ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Some modern critics had doubted the settle ment of Jews in Egypt until the third century But recent discoveries notably Mr. R. Mond's "Aramaic Papyri' prove that a Jewish commun ity existed in Egypt even in centuries preced ing Alexander.

Now persuasion ami the hope of profit drew many thousands of them to Alexandria, Cyrene, and other rentres of Hellenistic culture. In all these places they lived on terms of perfect equality with the Greek colonists.

The newly built city on the mouth of the Nile soon became a seat of Jewish influence and a school of learning for the Jewish nation Under the benign rule of the Ptolomies the Jews prospered, multiplied, and attained success in every walk of life, publie no less than private.

Of the five divisions of Alexandria they occupied nearly two. Egypt was then the granary of Europe and the corn trade lay largely in Jewish hands. Refinement came in the train of riches, and freedom begot tolerance.

The Jews cultivated Greek letters, and some of them became deeply imbued with the spirit of Greek philosophy and even of art. This friendly understanding between the Jewish and the Greek mind gave to the world the mystic union of Moses and Plato in the works of Philo and the Septuagint translation of the old Testament, which was to prepare the way for the advent of Christianity.

And yet the bulk of the Alexandrian Jews remained a peculiar people. Greeks and Egyptians had fused their religions into a common form of worship. But the Jews were still seperated from both races by the invincible barriers of belief, law, and custom. They still looked upon Jerusalem as their metropolis, and upon Alexandria as a mere place of exile In the midst of paganism they formed a mono theistic colony. Their houses of prayer were also schools of Levitical learning where the Torah was assiduously studied and expounded.
Their one link with the state their own Ernarch, who acted as supreme sovereign and judge of his people, and represented it at Court.
(From "Israel in Europe").

div.head: EGYPT'S BABIES.
NO RACE SUICIDE
div.p: There is no rare suicide in Egypt. From Alexandria to Assouan the country in filled with babies, round faced and solemn expres sioned I little tykes who look out upon the world with great eyes that are painted with kola, making their tiny faces appear top heavy, so large do they seem. As in all Oriental countries, children in Egypt are welcomed. The more the merrier The wife is not even considered a true wife until she becomes a mother. The estimation in which she is held, not only by her husband, but also by their friends, depends in a great degree upon her fruitfulness and upon the preservation of her children; for, by men and women, rich and poor, barrenness is considered a curse and a reproach So highly are babies esteemed in that strange country of the Nile that in the days before slavery was abolished a slave who contributed a child to her master's family circle and which he acknowledged as his own thereby earned her freedom according to the law ; and in the majority of instances she was further honored by being taken as her master's wife, or one of them, and becoming entitled to the luxuries of the harem So frequently do babies come, and so numerous are their deaths that the Egyptian government has never been able to procure a census that was at all satisfactory, and even the recent attempt made this year cannot be accepted as an official statement of the country's population. In Egypt births and deaths are not recorded except in the memories of those immediately concerned.

Three characteristics nf Egyptian babies impress themselves upon the tourist The first is their beauty ; for although many of them are blind, or nearly so, from uncleanliness and ophthalmia, they are all round faced and exquisitely modeled, their features are classically beautiful, and their color is exactly like bronze Self control is the next most impressive feature about these little folk, for it is a most unusual thing to hear an Egyptian baby cry Noticeable also is these little folks' usefulness. It would take a very indifferent person indeed to fail tonotice the infant toilers in Egypt.

div.head: A PHARAOH'S TOMB.
div.p: A most interesting account is given in "Blackwood by Mr. Weigall, the Chief In spector of Antiquities in Egypt, of the discovery of the tomb of Akhnaton. Not that the tomb and mummy of this Pharaoh were of themselves of greater value than those of other tinds. But the extraordinary character of this young man who ruled Egypt some two thousand four hundred years ago makes this discovery of last year of very great value Akhna ton began to reign when he was fifteen, and at once entered into a religious revolution. The Syrian sun god Aton was proclaimed the the only deity, and Aknaton his high priest. This, of course, raised the hostility of that powerful and conservative hierarchy, the priests of Aron Ba at Thebes. A temple dedicated to Aton was begun at Karnak, but eventually the young King chose a new site by the Nile, and there built a temple, a palace for himself, and houses for his nobles On the cliffs surrounding the new temple were inscriptions recording the oath of Pharaoh that he would never leave the place, ' but devote himself tn the religion of Aton. This religion was something more than sun worship, for Aton was the mysterious life giving power of which the sun was the symbol. Mr Weigall says,-

"The youthful High Priest called upon his followers to search tor their god not in the confusion of battle or behind the smoke of human sacrifices, but amidst the flowers and trees, amidst the wild duck and the fishes He preached an enlightened nature study a he was perhaps the first apostle of the simple life He strove to break down conventional religion, and ceaselessly urged his people to worship in truth, simple, without an excess of ceremonial."

We are also given some extracts from one of the hymns to Aton, and are told that thin hymn contains several verses almost identical with Psalm civ Forten years Akhnaton reigned and preached this gentle religion; after his death the old priesthood of Amon-Ra resumed its sway.
LATEST USE OF THE LIMERICK
"The "Limerick" has been used in a West-Country paper as the form in which to announce a birth. It runs:-
A story to yoft I will tell.
Of Mr. and Mrs. Follwell.
On Saturday morn
A baby was born,
Young Teddy was sound as a bell.

div.head: LIFE AT MEX.
A PHILOSOPHY OF NOISE.
div.p: Mex, Monday.

Opposite the house of which I am in temporary occupation are long rows of huge white, oblong blocks which appear to hare been fashioned entirely of cement. These block* are, in reality, composed of rubble, which, by the aid of cement, is made into a solid mass preventing a white and even surface. Everyday several of these blocks are manufactured and trains are continually carrying them away, as well as removing stone from the neighbour ing quarries. There are one of two engine* always occupied in shunting trucks. Day and night these is an incessant screaming of whistles, so much so, that for some time after my arrival, I was under the impression that I was the victim of a conspiracy of noise Now, after a fortnight's sojourn, I have become inured to the uproar which no longer keeps me awake by night or irritates me by day It has not however ceased to interest me, for it illustrates the predominant trait in the Egyptian character.

These engines, which pass to and from almost as ceaselessly as the wares break on the beach hard by, are usually manned by six or seven individuals with, occasionally, one or two more hanging on the footplates. Apparently the mission in life of at least one of the gentlemen on each engine is to blow a steam whistle in perpetuity, and, if this is so, he is assuredly a conscientious servant. Most Egyptians love to make a noise but only the few have such magnificent opportunities, nobly taken advantage of. If it were not for the blue of squealing an indiarubber "tootler" with every revolution of the wheel few Egyptians would ride a bicycle. But, during their shrill career through the crowded streets of a city, they are able to impress their individuality on a greater number of their fellow creatures than would be possible were they to squeeze the "tootler" all day long in the seclusion of their own backyard Hence the facilities offered by a bicycle for making themselves a travailing nuisance are unrivalled and claim the attention of all true-born Egyptians.

But there is a philosophy of noise of which, my friend on the engine is, perhaps, unaware. By his very industry he defeats the object which, presumably, he is paid to effect. The incessant shriek of the steam whistle no longer conveys a note of warning to the toilers in the vicinity of the railway track, for their cars, like mine, have become accustomed to it. Strangers introduced into a modem weaving shed are unable to communicate with each other owing to the din of the machinery, but the mill hands are so accustomed to the noise that they find it unnecessary to even raise their voices in ordinary conversation. If the whistle of the engine under consideration were to cease for five consecutive minutes their would certainly be a panic among the natives employed on the cement blocks. They would say "Allah" and a conviction would spread among them that "Ibrahim" was dead and the engine out of hand. A note of warning, to be effective, should be sudden, not continuous. No warning to a patient of an apoplectic ten dency is as effective as a slight stroke!

The love of noise is one of the chief characteristics of the Egyptian. Other nations have characteristics which, for a European, are equally difficult of comprehension A China man. for example, has an unaccountable predilection for unsavoury odours. He is happiest in a strong smell! That of a stale egg fills him with an unreasoning joy. He has an instinct for smells, and his earthly Paradise would inevitably comprise a garden of decayed cabbages.

An Egyptian is incapable of conceiving a silence which might be more effective than a noise, yet an Englishman, accustomed to speaking in public, recognises the value of a pause in his speeeh at the right moment, and it is the night which "makes a weird sound of its own stillness" which is the most awe inspiring. There is far too much unnecessary noise in the world, when, in some house in a crowded thoroughfare, a patient lies sick unto death, the physician orders straw or sawdust to be strewn on the road. The traffic goes on as usual but without noise. Muffled drum sticks are more impressive in their effect than naked ones and in a cavalry charge if the horses hoofs were enveloped in flannel the impact would be none the less

The Egyptian, moreover, loves to be unity in print. A certain Egyptian Nationalist journal published in English, which I occasionally peruse, would to my mind, be far more effective, if less blatant. In its illogical and windy denunciations of everything British it frequent ly. I venture to assert, defeats its own ends, and will, in the long run, prove its own extin guisher If the editor of the journal to which I refer were suddenly to disappear from the public here, his silence would be far more impressive than are his written words, but so long as he continuously blows a blatant trumpet in print he is in the way of defeatiug his own ends. The deepest rivers are also the most silent, and the sect which (if we are to believe the writer of an interesting article in a recent review is working secretly and patiently from a remote desert stronghold will eventually merit more serious consideration than the exponent of nationalist claims who airs his views day by day in our local press.
When the Egyptian has learnt the futility of noise he will be on the road to higher things.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: As the commissions of the "Formidable" type of battleships expire on the Mediterranean station-and they nearly all expire next year-they will be replaced by battleships of the "Canopus" type. THis has been already done in the case of the "Venerable" popularly known as "The Archdeacon" for a very obvious reason-by the battleship "Glory," Captain R. Phipps-Hornby, which has just joined the flag.
The old belted cruiser "Aurora," which was often a familiar object off Alexandria, has just been sold out of the service for £12,000, on the condition that she is broken up in the United Kingdom.

Early in the new year, the commissions of the first class cruisers "Lancaster," Captain Heath, M.V.O., and "Suffolk," Captain R. Wemyss, M.V.O., of the Third Cruiser Squadron, attached to the Mediterranean Fleet, will expire. Both cruisers will be recommissioned for another tour of service with Rear Admiral Sir H. Barry's squadron.

As at present arranged the 1st Battalion Suffolk Regiment, now at Woolwich, will embark at Southampton on the S.S. "Dongola" about the 20th prox en route for Malta, where it replaces the 1st Batralion Lancashire Fusilier-late at Cairo-ordered to Dagshai, India. The 1st Suffolks, which are commanded by Colonel F. Graham, with Major L.H. Bazalgette second in command, were last in Malta from 1897 till 1899, when they left for England, from where they went to South Africa for the campaign against the republics The "Dongola" will arrive at Valetta about the 27th, and on the same day the Lancashires will embark on her for Karachi, where she is due on the 11th December.

Captain H.S. Hearn, Royal Garrison Artillery, latterly doing duty with No. 7 Company at Gibraltar, has been appointed to, and seconded in his regiment for, service with the Egyptian Army. Captain Hearn has sprnt since 1895, and has held his present rank for the past six and half years. A portion of his service was spent in the Ordnance Department.

The Government is apparently wakening to the fact that there is a considerable distrust in the public mind re it economics in the way of naval reduction since it came into power. It has been pointed out amongst other things that the Mediterranean Fleet has been cut down to an absolutely dangerous limit in the pursuit of economy with efficiency. It is contended that in event of war-a not unlikely contingency, despite the peaceful platitutdes of cabinet ministers-the Channel, Atlantic and Home Fleets would have their hands full in home and European waters, and that the Mediterranean Fleet, as presented composed, is too weak to carry out the duties it would have to discharge, particularly in the protection of the Indian and Egyptian routes, and the very important service of supplementing the defence of Malta and Gibraltar. A short time ago, the Mediterranean Fleet consisted of twelve first class battleships, and twenty three cruisers, and some thirty smaller ships, gun-boats, destroyers, etc. To-day it comprises only six battleships, tour first class cruisers, three small cruisers, and eleven destroyers-in all 28 ships as compared to 62 this time three years ago. Gibraltar and Malta have been reduced to two repairing shops of little pretentions, and their garrisons have been cut down in carrying out the policy above referred to. It is understood the Imperial Defence Committee is giving this matter the attention it deserves, and that a pronouncement on it may be looked for here long.

div.head: A BERLIN MOTOR-CAR STORY.
div.p: An amusing story is current in Berlin. A few days agom as a motor car was turning a corner in the suburbs rather sharply the chauffeur, a well-to-do young merchant, observed a man carrying a gun and leading a wretched specimen of a dog. The sportsman jumped aside, but the car ran over the dog and killed it. The driver jumped down from the car. When he saw the corpse of the dog he asked the "sportsman" whether he would be satisfied with twenty shillings to cover the loss of the dog. The man accepted the money gladly and the young merchant got into his car. Before driving away, he said to the stranger: "I am very sorry that I have spoilt your shooting for to-day." "Oh, I was not going shooting," replied the man with the gun. "Well, what where you going to do with that gun" asked the man in the car. "Oh, I was just going to shoot my dog in the wood," answered the "sportsman," as he strolled away with a smile on his face.

div.head: PE-RU-NA CHEERFULLY RECOMMENDED FOR COLDS AND CATARRH.
div.p: A Prominent Canadian Gives His Experience With the World-Famous Remedy for Catarrh.
Chronic Catarrh Always Begins With An Ordinary Cold.
So Says Dr. Hartman, the Greatest Living Authority on Catarrhal Diseases.
The first effect of a cold is a thickening of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat.
This given time to a discharge, or at least a stuffiness of the nasal pendages.
Sometimes fever accompanies the first attack, also a feeling of languor, dullness and sobing of the bones.
If no attention is paid to it, the mucous congestion is liable to spread down into the parynx, producting horaseness and into the bronchial tubes, producing a cough.
Even when this occurs, many people pay no attention to it.

Under such circumstances, the congestion is liable to become chronic, produeling a condition of the mucous membranes known as estarrh. Catarrh lasts an indefinite time. Catarrh is essentially chronic condition and does not leave except something is done to relieve it.
CURE COLDS-PREVENT CATARRH.
What should be done when a person catches cold is to take a few doses of Peruna.
Taken at the onset, Peruns would break up the cold and prevent all the train of symptoms which usually follow.
But, even in cases where the cold has been neglected and hoarseness or a cough has developed. Peruna can be relied upon to give prompt and permanent relief.
The frequency of coughs and colds in the winter makes Peruna a popular remedy for these ailment.
A number of the best people of various countries have given testimoniais as to the value of Peruna in such cases.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui a midi)
div.p: Ainsi que le faisait prévoir la mauvaiae tendance d'hier, notre marché a été notable ment déprimé oe matin. Tout le monde voulait liquider à la foin, et les acheteur» faisant défaut, il n'est pas étonnant que la cote ait subi une nouvelle atteinte. On attribue oette hâte générale A liquider à plusieurs raisons, d'abord à la hausse continue de cm derniers tempe, puis A l'hésitation des marchés européens et auxjiouvelles pins ou moins rassurante* d'Amé nque, mai» par dessus tout au déeir pour les uns de réaliser au plu» tût le bénéfice acquis et pour les autres à l'obligation imposée par les banques de clôturer certains comptes A la faveur le 1* reprise actuelle. Les liquidations graduelles de la Cassa di Sconto et de quelques autres sociétés viennent encore ajouter au tas raient Mai» dora que signifiait! effervescence extraordinaire qui régnait depuis quelques se mainee dans notre corbeille, la hansse continue de toute une catégorie de titres, et la prétendue absence de vendeurs ! Aujourd'hui que ceux-ci e présentent et Dieu sait en quel nombre, sont les acheteurs qni s'éclipsent. Nous avions donc raison de dire naguère qu'il faut se me fier du jour ois sur un marché tout le monde s'affiche comme acheteur et haussier.

Le résultat d'un tel état de chose* se réunie naturellement en peu d'affaire*, effectuée à des prix intérieur» et disséminée* un peu sur toutes les valeurs offertes, en particulier la National Bank, l'Agricole, le Comptoir, et dans de moindres proportion* l'United, la Building Landa, l'Urbaine et le* Nungovich Hotel*. Encore une fois, il a agit de transaction» minimes et clairsemée*, une partie des courtiers ayant déserté la corbeille.

div.head: LA BELGIQUE ET L'EGYPTE
div.p: (Suite et fin)

Il eat particulièrement' heureux d entendre un langage an mi rassurant de le pert dune personne aussi enfarinée, oar c'est un symptôme que dans les hautes spheres on ne considère pas la crise actuelle comme ayant touché d'une façon serieuse aux racines de la vraie prospérité du pays et c'eut par des déclarations de œ genre uniquement que l'on pourra rassurer vraiment l'opinion publique européenne, surtout an point de vue commercial et financier, sur le sort de I Egypte, que l'on s eat vraiment trop plu en Europe à comparer à celui de la Répu blique Argentine

La suite do rapport a trait aux Sociétés et Entreprises Belges ayant l' Egypte pour champ d activité. On peat évaluer actuellement a 400 trillions de franco, les capitaux belges travailstant en Egypte et ce chiffre peut être regardecomme plutôt au dessous de la réalité. Après avoir examiné la situation de ces sociétés et entreprises, M le Baron de Gaither donne quelques renseignements sur l'état des travaux d agrandissement du Port d'Alexandrie, sur les Chemins de Fer Egyptiens, et passe ensuite en revue le commerce extérieur de l'Egypte, ana lysant la part prise par les divers pays à l'Itn [inrtation en Egypte. Ixs pays qui ont collaboré pour la plus grande partie à l'accroissement desimportations sont. 1 Angleterre pour 25.540.000 franca, la France pour 12 000.000 de francs, la Mgique pourr 10.600 000 de francs, l'Allemagne pour 310.000 francs, l'Autriche Hongrie pour 5.685.000 francs, la Russie pour & 532.000 francs, l'Amérique pour 3 160.000 franca, etc

La Belgique poor lee importations vient maintenant au sixième rang juste après l'Allemagne et avant l'Italie, et sa part de participation au commerce gênerai d'importation a passe de 3,8 pour cent en 1905 a 5,1 pour rent en 1906 C'est le pays dont le pourcentage - est le plus rapidement accru et il est curieux de noter que le pourcentage de participation de (Angleterre aux importations n'a presque pas varié d une année l'antre 32,7 pour rent an contre 32,2 pour cent en 1905 Voici par ordre d'importance les principaux articles im portée par la Belgique en 1906 pour certains entre eux, elle est en quelque sorte maîtresse du marché ; pour d'au très, elle a conquis une place brillante) Per et acier ouvrée (L.E 362.659) , Ferronnerie L E. 168.589). Wagons LE 163.163); Engrais Chimiques (LE 76.259 Ciments (LE. 60.355); Verres à vitre (LE 43.030). Sucres (LE 85 158 contre LE 271 en 1904 ') Pannes (L E 28 151 contre LE 87 en 1904) Tissus de Lin (LE 27 674); Glaceset Miroirs (LE 24.559); Serrurerie (LE 17 Blanc de Zinc (LE. 16.648); puis viennent le Fer fondu, les Verreries, les Annes,l«i Faiences et Porcelaines, les Tissus de Coton, le Bronze et le Zinc, les Produits Chimiques, les Appareils Electriques les Machines Elec triques, les Machines et parties de machines, les Couvertures de coton, les Couleurs, les Tissus de Laine, la Quincaillerie, le Charbon.

Le Ministre de Belgique au Caire ne s'est pas borné a donner une suite de tableaux, il les a fait suivre d'une véritable étude détaillée des diverses rubriques des tableaux statist) ques de la Douane Egyptienne, profitant de l'occasion pour y joindre de précieux rensei gnements pour les exportateurs belges.

Citons ceux qn il donne snr lew Tissus de Coton, la Bonneterie, les Métanx et Ouvra ges en Métal, les Automobiles, les Peaux et Ouvrages en Peau, les Céréales, Légumes et Farines. l'indigo Artificiel, les Engrais Chimiques, pour ne parler que des principaux C'est assez dire le soin minutieux qui a présidé à la ronfpction d'un tel rapport, intéressant jusque dans ses moindres détails, et qui permet ainsi au commerce belge de se rendre compte du chemin parcouru d'une année a Vautre.

Avant de conclure en engageant les Belges à encore accroître davantage leur activité commerciale en Egypte par la création de nou veaux établissements commerciaux, M le Ba ron de Gaiffier donne de bons conseil aux commerçants de Belgique, sur le choix des représentants, l'envoi de commis voyageurs, les catalogues, échantillons et autres moyens de réclame, les crédita et aussi sur l'importante question des emballages, qui, dit il, 'doivent "être aussi soigné» et aussi solides que si les "marchandises étaient destinées à la Chinc "et au Japon." Ce dernier point est trés exact, car ce qui fait souvent la force d'une nation commerciale pour tel ou tel article, c'est Ja sûreté que peut avoir l'acheteur de le recevoi en bon etat et sans avarie, de façon à pouvoir le vendre on l'utiliser de suite.
CH. RUELENS,
Licencie en Sciences Commerciales et Consulaires, et Boursier Commercial du Gouvernement Belge en Egypte.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: Applications (in writing only) for places as clerks in the Sudan Branch of the Egyptian Irrigation Service will be received at the Ministry of Public Works up to the 25th October by the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan.
Some educational qualifications and a good knowledge of English is essential. Pay L.E. 8 to L.E. 15 per month according to qualifications.

Applications should state qualifications and experience and give references and should be accompanied by copies of certificates; and should be addressed to the Inspector General of Irrigation for the Sudan, Public Works Ministry, Cairo, in envelopes labelled "Application for post of clerk."

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'il sera procede, le Vendredi dix-huit Octobre courant, a neuf heures du matin aux Magasins Generaux de Boulac (Cairo), a la Vente aux encheres publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, de cent tonnes environ de vieux bois et dechets hors d'usage provenant des travaux du Service des Ponts, qui se trouvent an chantier du Service des Ponts a Ramlet Boulac (Caire), ou on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a midi, les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes.

Les conditions de vente relatives a ces materiaux peuvent etre consulteesau Bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux a Boulac, Caire, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a une heure p.m. les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes

Pour etre admis a concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au prealable, verser a la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire, une somme de L.E. 10 (dix Livres Egyptiennes) a titre de depot provisoire. Le soumissionnaire declare adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montantde l'offre agreee et enlever a ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjuges dans un delai de trente jours a compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront etre taites sur papier timbre de trente milliemes, si l'interesse ne peut pas assister aux encheres publiques, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le recu du versement du depot provisoire seront adresses par la poste sous pli recommande a:
"Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Genraux des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a Boulac Caire"
et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour Achat de vieux bois et de dechets."
Toute offre faite ou deposee ulterieure ment au jour et a l'heure ci=dessus designes ne sera pas prise en consideration.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter les prix les plus eleves ni a donner suite aux soumissions presentees. Elle se reserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 9 Octobre 1907.

div.head: NILE GAUGE READINGS
div.p: OCTOBER 1906-1907

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au Lundi 16 Decembreprochain, a midi au plus tard, des offre pour la construction des maconneries de tondation et des maconneries d'elevation des piles et culees, ainsi que la fourniture, la construction et le montage de la partie metallique d'un nouveau pont a deux voies, a establir a Kocheicha, au point kilometrique 95+740 de la lignedu Caire a Louxor et ce conformement a toutes les conditions generales, a la description generale des travaux, aux clauses generales de l'entreprise et aux desseins annexes au cahier des Charges relatif a cette adjudication, duquel un exemplaire complet sera mis a la disposition des intresses sur leurs demandes au bureau de mM> le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux de Boulac (Caire) et a celui de M. l'Inspecteur des Magasins Generaux a Alexandrie contre paiement de £1 (Une Livre Sterling).

Toute personne desirant prendre part a cette adjudication, devra en meme temps qu'elle presentera son offre et sous peine de nullite de celle-ci, effecteur a la Caisse de l'Administration des CHemins de Fer un cantionnement provisoire en especes ou en titres de la Dette Egyptienne de la valeur de L.E. 500 (Livres Egyptiennes cinq cents). Le soumissionnaire declare adjudicataire devra, dans un delai de huit jours apres l'acceptation en principe de son offre, deposer dans la susdite caisse nn cautionnement de Livres Egyptiennes deux mille cinq cents.

Les soumissions devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de trente milliemes, sinsi que du recu du versement du cautionnement provisoire. Elles seront adresses sous pli recommande et cachete a:
Monsieur le Directeur General des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat au Caire (Egypte)
et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription auivante:
"Offre pour la construction d'un Pont a deux voies a Kocheicha".

L'Administration se reserve le droit de ne donner sucune suite aux soumissions presentees, quel que soit le prix soumis: elle sera libra de choisir l'offre qui lui paraltra la plus scantageuse, notamment au point de vue du delai d'execution, sans etre tenue d'accepter celle qui sera la plus basse.
Le Caire, le 7 Octobre 1907. 31064-2-1

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public que le bureau telegraphique de San Stefano a ete ferme.
Le Caire, le Octobre 1907. 31093-2-2

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer et Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public qu'a partir du 15 courant et pendant la saison cotonniere, le bureau telegraphique de Chabas recevra les telegrammes en langues Europeenes.
Le Caire, le 10 Octobre 1907. 31085-2-2

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
AVIS
div.p: L'adjudication pour la fourniture de 400 grilles pour puisards et de 200 regards de visite a ete revoyee jusqu'au 5 Novembreprochain.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L.Eg. 75.
Le cahier des charges est depose au bureau Technique ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9h. a midi, les jours teries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adresses sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 5 Novembre 1907.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission" pour fourniture grilles et puisards".

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite general avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 5 Novembre 1907a midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci=dessus sera ecartee.
Alexandrie le 14/10/07.
Le Vice-President:
31104-3-1(signe) Dr Schiess.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: THE STANDARD LIFE ASSURANCE CO.
ESTABLISHED 1825.
div.p: ACCUMULATED FUNDS £11,750,000.
ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES with guaranteed bonus on survival of 2 per annum for each 100 of assurance.
CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENTS at low rates, with return of all premiums paid in the event of death before the given age is attained.

ENDOWMENT ASSURANCES WITH GUARANTEED BONUS ON SURVIVAL.-A, aged 30 next birthday, with Good prospect of longevity, takes out a Policy of £1,000 under this table for an Endowment Assurance payable at the age of 60 or earlier death, with a Guaranteed Bonus of 40s. per cent per annum. If he survives the fixed term, the annual premium for which will be £38:15:0. In the event of death within the 30 yearsm only the sum assured in the Policy is payable, viz:- £1,000, but if he survives the term, he is entitled to receive besides £1,000, a Guaranteed Bonus of 30 times 40s. per cent; i.c. £800, or in all £600; and similarly for other periods and rates, Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired.

CHILDREN'S ENDOWMENT.- An annual Premium of £18:1:3 will provide a child aged 1 next birthday with an Endowment of £500 on attaining the age of 21. In the event of the child's death before the given age is attained, all the premiums paid to the Company will be return to the parent. Premiums can be paid quarterly or half-yearly if desired. Should the parent wish to discontinue the payment of premiums, he can claim a surrender value of 90 per cent of all the annual premiums paid by him, excepting the first, providing three full years premiums have been paid and the transaction is completed while the Policy is in force. Should the parent not wish to take the surrender value, he has the option, after three full years' premiums have been paid, of receiving a Paid-up Policy for such a proportion of the original Sum Assured as the number of payments made bears to the whole number payable. If written application be made and the transaction completed within the days of grace, and provided such proportion be not less than £50.
For Prospectus, Forms of Proposal and all particulars, apply to the STANDARD LIFE OFFICE, STANDARD BUILDINGS, CAIRO.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It is simply weakness-a break-down, asit were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality-vigour-
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrates life-reviving tonic
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored.
